of monatomic ions to the zabuyelite surface would not be
expected to produce their own bands in the IR spectrum.
However, changing the chemistry of carbonate nearest cation
neighbors produces a measurable diﬀerence in the stretching
Therefore, the spectral position of the
carbonate asymmetrical stretch was assessed using ATR-IR.
Sulfate band positions were compared with a 0.33 M Na
the same broad bands were observed at 740, 858, 1087, and
in the solid phase consistent with the DRIFTS
analysis. Sulfate in solution produced an intense band at 1096
that is related to the asymmetrical stretch of the
exposed to a 0.33 M sulfate solution show a shift of this band
c). No other evidence for adsorption
other crystalline carbonate materials such as calcite, Li
has an inverse solubility, whereby the solubility of the solid
solutions (both 0.5 M) should result in a very high
supersaturation with respect to zabuyelite. In other carbonate
systems, high supersaturation levels lead to the formation of
amorphous precursor phases that transform into the ﬁnal
In our experiments, we do not see direct
evidence for a precursor phase. However, we repeatedly
observe that the rosette crystal arrangement produced
throughout our experiments have a hollow core. This is
unusual as rosettes are typically proposed to form due to
structural interactions between the diﬀerent crystal arms, such
as aragonite rosettes formed in the presence of nonionic
Similarly, in ice rosettes, whose crystals have a very
similar shape to that of zabuyelite, the core is solid and
hollow structures penetrating into the center of individual
structure has also been observed in ice formation and is
tion of less crystalline Ca-carbonate into a crystalline phase has
been shown to form hollow structures in some experiments.
Thus, the presence of channels within our crystals and hollow
centers of the rosettes indicates that zabuyelite may also
precipitate via transformation from a precursor phase.
4.2. Inﬂuence of Monovalent Ions on Li Carbonate
Unlike zabuyelite, Na and K-carbonates have high
solubility, which for K-carbonate increases with elevated
The absence of these minerals in the
precipitated phases is consistent with the expected higher
thermodynamic stability of zabuyelite with respect to these
will not compete directly for carbonate
via the growth of additional solid phases, the main inﬂuence of
these ions will be on the chemistry of the system. For example,
Na-carbonate ion pairs were predicted based on the
PHREEQC simulations. Incorporation of the mineral con-
stituent ion into an ion pair with a nonconstituent ion can
signiﬁcantly lower the supersaturation of the solution with
respect to the mineral of interest.
for nucleation doubled in the presence of 1 M NaCl in
comparison to the additive free experiments. However, the
formation of rosettes with hollow cores indicates that the
supersaturation remained high despite the formation of Na-
The presence of background ions can have an indirect eﬀect
on the hydration of mineral constituent ions in solution. This
may be important for Li-carbonate growth as Li
to have a coherent ﬁrst hydration shell due to the strong
electrostatic ﬁelds that are expected for small cations
of covalent character in its interaction with the water molecules
This eﬀect results in a shorter
distance between the water molecules and Li
The presence of background ions is
proposed to be able to disturb the hydration shell of ions
facilitating nucleation and growth, known as “salting out”. Such
decreases in solubility can be observed in carbonate phases,
such as calcite, at high ionic strengths of solution.
Table 4. Adsorption Energies Calculated for Diﬀerent Brine Components and the Resultant Change in Surface Energies
Computational simulations of zabuyelite. (a) Bulk structure
of zabuyelite, where the green sphere: Li, black spheres: C and red
spheres: O. The green polyhedra show the tetrahedral Li sites. (b)
Predicted equilibrium morphology of the dry zabuyelite crystal in
vacuo based on the surface energies of the most stable surfaces.
